turns.speaker: ELIZABETH
turns.text: So I'll meet you at the restaraunt?

turns.speaker: LENA
turns.text: Ok.

turns.speaker: ELIZABETH
turns.text: They need to see the new 484's to make sure it works with their OC....

turns.speaker: LENA
turns.text: Ok. What should I do about Eric?

turns.speaker: ELIZABETH
turns.text: Just tell him to call me.

turns.speaker: LENA
turns.text: Ok.

turns.speaker: ELIZABETH
turns.text: So...did my brother call you?

turns.speaker: LENA
turns.text: No.

turns.speaker: ELIZABETH
turns.text: I have no idea what he's doing then. I'm sorry that didn't work out.

turns.speaker: LENA
turns.text: It's fine.

turns.speaker: ELIZABETH
turns.text: You wouldn't want to go out with him anyway, honestly, he's such a freak sometimes.

turns.speaker: LENA
turns.text: He did seem a little strange.

turns.speaker: ELIZABETH
turns.text: Well...he's not that strange, don't say that.

turns.speaker: LENA
turns.text: I'm sorry. You're right.

turns.speaker: ELIZABETH
turns.text: I think he's weird, but that's me.

turns.speaker: LENA
turns.text: Should I call you later?

turns.speaker: ELIZABETH
turns.text: I'll just see you when you get back here.

turns.speaker: LENA
turns.text: Ok.

turns.speaker: ROYER-COLLARD
turns.text: Welcome to Charenton, Abbe du Maupas.

turns.speaker: ABBE DU MAUPAS
turns.text: I'm pleased to have the new post, sir.

turns.speaker: ROYER-COLLARD
turns.text: I'm afraid that our endowment has shrivelled to a mere pittance; we're the laughing stock of all France. But -- on a happier note --

turns.speaker: ROYER-COLLARD
turns.text: -- and the listless ones do the binding.

turns.speaker: ABBE DU MAUPAS
turns.text: It's remarkable, Doctor. The patients are so subdued; so docile.

turns.speaker: ROYER-COLLARD
turns.text: They've the satisfaction only a hard day's labor can provide.

turns.speaker: ABBE DU MAUPAS
turns.text: I don't believe it. The Marquis de Sade? You're actually publishing his novels?

turns.speaker: ROYER-COLLARD
turns.text: Ever since his unfortunate death, there's been a surge of interest in his work. I'll use the profits to restore Charenton to her former glory.

turns.speaker: ROYER-COLLARD
turns.text: Of course, everything's not as harmonious as it seems. I hope you've a strong constitution.

turns.speaker: ABBE DU MAUPAS
turns.text: My years tending the lepers at St. Emilion steeled me for life's grisliest offerings, Doctor.

turns.speaker: ROYER-COLLARD
turns.text: We've still a few lone incurables. Prone to violence, to perversion.

turns.speaker: MADELEINE
turns.text: "And so the Professor lifted Colombe's skirt high, above her waist. 'Let me be your Tutor,' said he, 'in the ways of love.' With that, he slid her pantalettes down, down, down over her knees, and there -- nestled between her legs -- as pink as a tulip, as slick as an eel --"

turns.speaker: CHARLOTTE
turns.text: We oughtn't be reading his nasty stories --

turns.speaker: MADELEINE
turns.text: No one's forcing you to listen.

turns.speaker: CHARLOTTE
turns.text: You've been to his quarters, haven't you?

turns.speaker: MADELEINE
turns.text: Once or twice.

turns.speaker: CHARLOTTE
turns.text: I hear he's got a whetstone and chisel, and he uses them to sharpen his teeth.

turns.speaker: MADELEINE
turns.text: He's a writer, not a madman.

turns.speaker: CHARLOTTE
turns.text: Then what's he doing here?

turns.speaker: MADELEINE
turns.text: If you're going to slander him, then you don't deserve to hear his stories --

turns.speaker: CHARLOTTE
turns.text: I think she's sweet on him, that's what I think.

turns.speaker: CLEANTE
turns.text: Marquis? Is that you?

turns.speaker: THE MARQUIS
turns.text: For fuck's sake, who else would it be? The witching hour's arrived; you've alerted the others, yes?

turns.speaker: CLEANTE
turns.text: I'm no longer a man! I awoke to discover I'd turned into a sparrow!

turns.speaker: THE MARQUIS
turns.text: Yes, well, I awoke to discover I'd turned into a cat. If you don't do as I say, I'll sink my little fangs into your drumsticks, and suck the marrow straight out of your bones.

turns.speaker: CLEANTE
turns.text: At your service, Count.

turns.speaker: THE MARQUIS
turns.text: Now give the signal.

turns.speaker: THE MARQUIS
turns.text: "One day, Fanchon's first client was a surgeon. He ran his fingers across her naked skin, pulling apart folds of flesh, inspecting each and every follicle..."

turns.speaker: CLEANTE
turns.text: "One day, Fanchon was visited by a surgeon. He ran his fingers across her naked skin, pulling apart folds of flesh, inspecting follicles..."

turns.speaker: THE MARQUIS
turns.text: "With that, Fanchon expelled a scream so extravagantly pitched, that the surgeon was obliged to tear out her tongue --"

turns.speaker: CLEANTE
turns.text: "With that, Fanchon expelled a scream so extravagantly pitched, that the surgeon was obliged to tear out her tongue --"

turns.speaker: THE MARQUIS
turns.text: "To seal the wound, he took a poker from the fire --"

turns.speaker: CLEANTE
turns.text: "...a poker... he took a poker from the fire..."

turns.speaker: MADELEINE
turns.text: Then how can we know who is truly good, and who is evil?

turns.speaker: COULMIER
turns.text: We can't. All we can do is guard against our own corruption.

turns.speaker: COULMIER
turns.text: Madeleine --

turns.speaker: MADELEINE
turns.text: Yes, Abbe?

turns.speaker: COULMIER
turns.text: The next time you feel the urge to visit the Marquis, I hope you'll come to confession instead.

turns.speaker: COULMIER
turns.text: Has he hurt you?

turns.speaker: MADELEINE
turns.text: His stinking breath caused my eyes to run, that's all.

turns.speaker: MADELEINE
turns.text: I was wrong to free him, but so are you -- for taking all his treasures -- his quills and his ink --

turns.speaker: COULMIER
turns.text: Not now, or we're both done for.

turns.speaker: COULMIER
turns.text: Had I known your taste in novels, I never would've taught you to read.

turns.speaker: MADELEINE
turns.text: Don't say that; reading's my salvation.

turns.speaker: COULMIER
turns.text: But why must you indulge in his pornography?

turns.speaker: MADELEINE
turns.text: It's a hard day's wages, slaving away for madmen. What I've seen in life, it takes a lot to hold my interest.

turns.speaker: MADELEINE
turns.text: Ow!

turns.speaker: COULMIER
turns.text: But why heap such ghastly fantasies atop an already ghastly existence?

turns.speaker: MADELEINE
turns.text: I put myself in his stories. I play the parts. Each strumpet, each murderess.

turns.speaker: COULMIER
turns.text: Why not act the role of heroines instead? Queen Esther from the Bible, or St. Joan?

turns.speaker: MADELEINE
turns.text: If I wasn't such a bad woman on the page, Abbe, I'll hazard I couldn't be such a good woman in life.

turns.speaker: COULMIER
turns.text: In part, yes.

turns.speaker: MADELEINE
turns.text: He's not the man who's cast a shadow here.

turns.speaker: COULMIER
turns.text: The Doctor's a respected man, a friend of the court --

turns.speaker: MADELEINE
turns.text: I haven't been to see the Marquis for ages. And I won't -- ever again -- I swear it. I won't speak to him, I won't even utter his name --

turns.speaker: COULMIER
turns.text: Is that a promise you can truly keep?

turns.speaker: COULMIER
turns.text: Charenton has changed; it's not safe for you here.

turns.speaker: MADELEINE
turns.text: I've you to look after me, haven't I?

turns.speaker: MADELEINE
turns.text: Don't turn us out, Abbe.

turns.speaker: COULMIER
turns.text: "Turn you out?"

turns.speaker: MADELEINE
turns.text: It's a sin against God for me to refuse your kindness. But my heart's held fast here...

turns.speaker: COULMIER
turns.text: By whom? The Marquis?

turns.speaker: MADELEINE
turns.text: Mother's not half so blind as you.

turns.speaker: COULMIER
turns.text: Madeleine, I... there are certain things... feelings... we must not voice.

turns.speaker: MADELEINE
turns.text: Why not?

turns.speaker: COULMIER
turns.text: They incite us to act. In ways we should not... cannot... a lesson the Marquis would do well to learn.

turns.speaker: COULMIER
turns.text: Go back to your room. Quickly.

turns.speaker: MADELEINE
turns.text: What? What've I done?

turns.speaker: COULMIER
turns.text: Don't come back, not tonight, not again --

turns.speaker: MADELEINE
turns.text: You'll hate me now, won't you?

turns.speaker: COULMIER
turns.text: If you'd grant me a final favor, I'd like the chance to explain myself --

turns.speaker: MADELEINE
turns.text: Don't come any closer, Abbe. God's watching.

turns.speaker: VALCOUR
turns.text: They've got no right, sending someone to sit on your shoulder. I work for you; I won't take orders from a stranger.

turns.speaker: COULMIER
turns.text: You needn't worry, Valcour. It's administrative, nothing more.

turns.speaker: COULMIER
turns.text: Free his mouth.

turns.speaker: VALCOUR
turns.text: Mustn't do that, sir.

turns.speaker: COULMIER
turns.text: I must grant him his last rites.

turns.speaker: VALCOUR
turns.text: I don't take my orders from you; not anymore.

turns.speaker: COULMIER
turns.text: You'd deny a dying man his salvation?

turns.speaker: THE MARQUIS
turns.text: Care for a splash of wine, Abbe?

turns.speaker: COULMIER
turns.text: It's not even noon --

turns.speaker: THE MARQUIS
turns.text: Conversation, like certain portions of the anatomy, always runs more smoothly when it's lubricated.

turns.speaker: THE MARQUIS
turns.text: I should've told you it was the blood of Christ; you'd believe that, wouldn't you?

turns.speaker: COULMIER
turns.text: We treat you well enough here, don't we Marquis? Your very own featherbed, in lieu of a straw mat. Your antique writing desk, all the way from LaCoste. Enough quills to feather an ostrich --

turns.speaker: THE MARQUIS
turns.text: It's true, dear-heart, you've spoiled me pink.

turns.speaker: COULMIER
turns.text: In exchange, we ask only that you follow the rules. Now you know as well as I do... you're not to entertain visitors in your quarters.

turns.speaker: THE MARQUIS
turns.text: I'm entertaining you now, aren't I?

turns.speaker: COULMIER
turns.text: I'm not a beautiful young prospect, ripe for corruption.

turns.speaker: THE MARQUIS
turns.text: Don't be so sure.

turns.speaker: COULMIER
turns.text: Take your pen in hand, Marquis. Purge these wicked thoughts of yours on paper; maybe they'll govern you less in life.

turns.speaker: THE MARQUIS
turns.text: I'll fill page after page, I promise.

turns.speaker: THE MARQUIS
turns.text: Yes! It is! The paper's cheap, the type's too small --

turns.speaker: COULMIER
turns.text: What did you do? Bribe one of the guards?

turns.speaker: THE MARQUIS
turns.text: But you implored me to write! For curative purposes, to stave off my madness --

turns.speaker: COULMIER
turns.text: But you've no right to publish! Behind my back, without my sanction!

turns.speaker: THE MARQUIS
turns.text: Have you truly read the book in question? Or did you run -- straightaway -- to the dog-eared pages?

turns.speaker: COULMIER
turns.text: Enough to discern its tenor.

turns.speaker: THE MARQUIS
turns.text: And --?

turns.speaker: COULMIER
turns.text: It's not even a proper novel! It's nothing but an encyclopedia of perversions! Frankly, it even fails as an exercise in craft. The characters are wooden; the dialogue is inane. Not to mention the endless repetition of words like "nipple" and "pikestaff" --

turns.speaker: THE MARQUIS
turns.text: There I was taxed; it's true.

turns.speaker: COULMIER
turns.text: And such puny scope! Nothing but the very worst in man's nature!

turns.speaker: THE MARQUIS
turns.text: I write of the great, eternal truths that bind together all mankind! The whole world over, we eat, we shit, we fuck, we kill and we die.

turns.speaker: COULMIER
turns.text: But we also fall in love; we build cities, we compose symphonies, and we endure. Why not put that in your books as well?

turns.speaker: THE MARQUIS
turns.text: It's a fiction, not a moral treatise.

turns.speaker: COULMIER
turns.text: But isn't that the duty of art? To elevate us above the beast?

turns.speaker: THE MARQUIS
turns.text: I thought that was your duty, Abbe, not mine.

turns.speaker: COULMIER
turns.text: One more trick like this, and I'll be forced to revoke all your liberties!

turns.speaker: THE MARQUIS
turns.text: It's that Doctor fellow, isn't it? He's come to usurp your place here, hasn't he?

turns.speaker: COULMIER
turns.text: More than your writing's at stake. The Ministry has threatened us with closure.

turns.speaker: THE MARQUIS
turns.text: They can't be serious.

turns.speaker: COULMIER
turns.text: Our future lies in the stroke of your pen.

turns.speaker: THE MARQUIS
turns.text: Mightier than the sword indeed.

turns.speaker: COULMIER
turns.text: Put yourself in my place. I've your fellow patients to consider. If Charenton falls, they've no place to go. No manner in which to clothe or feed themselves --

turns.speaker: THE MARQUIS
turns.text: Fuck 'em! They're half-wits and pinheads. Let 'em die on the streets, as Nature intended.

turns.speaker: COULMIER
turns.text: You among them?

turns.speaker: THE MARQUIS
turns.text: You've a touch of the poet, too; perhaps you should take up the quill.

turns.speaker: COULMIER
turns.text: Do I have your word?

turns.speaker: COULMIER
turns.text: If you only mean to dupe me again --

turns.speaker: THE MARQUIS
turns.text: Honestly! You cut me to the core! What's the point of all your valiant attempts at rehabilitation if -- when I finally succumb -- when at long last, I pledge myself to righteous conduct -- you regard me with nothing but suspicion? Have you no faith in your own medicine?

turns.speaker: COULMIER
turns.text: You mean to take us all down with you?

turns.speaker: THE MARQUIS
turns.text: Don't be absurd; it's only a play.

turns.speaker: THE MARQUIS
turns.text: He can't do that to me.

turns.speaker: COULMIER
turns.text: How can one man possibly be so selfish?

turns.speaker: THE MARQUIS
turns.text: We held a mirror up to the Doctor, and -- apparently -- he didn't like what he saw.

turns.speaker: THE MARQUIS
turns.text: What the devil --

turns.speaker: COULMIER
turns.text: If you won't be true to your word, then you've left me no choice.

turns.speaker: COULMIER
turns.text: Perhaps -- in time -- you'll earn them back through good behavior --

turns.speaker: THE MARQUIS
turns.text: You can't --! You mustn't --! I've all the demons of hell in my head; my only salvation is to vent them on paper --

turns.speaker: COULMIER
turns.text: Try reading, for a change. The writer who produces more than he reads? The sure mark of an amateur.

turns.speaker: COULMIER
turns.text: Start with the Bible; it's cheerier, and more artfully written.

turns.speaker: THE MARQUIS
turns.text: That monstrous God of yours? He strung up his very own son like a side of veal; I shudder to think what He'd do to me.

turns.speaker: COULMIER
turns.text: You know what sacrilege is, don't you? The last refuge of the failed provocateur.

turns.speaker: THE MARQUIS
turns.text: I'll die of loneliness! I've no company but the characters I create --

turns.speaker: COULMIER
turns.text: Whores and pederasts? You're better off without them.

turns.speaker: THE MARQUIS
turns.text: I have a proposition.

turns.speaker: COULMIER
turns.text: You always do.

turns.speaker: THE MARQUIS
turns.text: Madeleine. She's besotted with me; she'd do anything I ask. She could pay you a midnight visit --

turns.speaker: COULMIER
turns.text: I don't know who you insult more; her or me.

turns.speaker: THE MARQUIS
turns.text: "Part the gates of heaven," as it were --

turns.speaker: COULMIER
turns.text: That's enough.

turns.speaker: THE MARQUIS
turns.text: You're tense, darling. You could use a long, slow screw.

turns.speaker: COULMIER
turns.text: Good day, Marquis.

turns.speaker: THE MARQUIS
turns.text: THEN BUGGER ME!

turns.speaker: THE MARQUIS
turns.text: My bed, gone! Am I to freeze to death?

turns.speaker: COULMIER
turns.text: His rug.

turns.speaker: THE MARQUIS
turns.text: And my chaise -- am I being denied the privilege of sitting -- of plopping down my ass --

turns.speaker: THE MARQUIS
turns.text: That's a Turkish weave, you numbskull; it costs more than you'll earn in your lifetime --

turns.speaker: COULMIER
turns.text: Valcour. His chair.

turns.speaker: THE MARQUIS
turns.text: Virgin birth -- ha! An entire religion, built on an oxymoron!

turns.speaker: COULMIER
turns.text: Orvolle. His wine.  From now on, nothing but water at every meal --

turns.speaker: THE MARQUIS
turns.text: -- water! --

turns.speaker: COULMIER
turns.text: -- and your meat shall be de-boned.

turns.speaker: THE MARQUIS
turns.text: WHY THIS SUDDEN TORTURE?

turns.speaker: COULMIER
turns.text: Because your writing continues, unchecked.

turns.speaker: THE MARQUIS
turns.text: I DIDN'T CREATE THIS WORLD OF OURS! I ONLY RECORD IT!

turns.speaker: COULMIER
turns.text: Its horrors, perhaps! Its darkest nightmares! And to what end? Nothing but your own morbid gratification --

turns.speaker: THE MARQUIS
turns.text: Morbid gratification? NO! I write what I've seen; the endless procession to the chopping block. We're all lined up at the guillotine, waiting for the crunch of the blade. Rivers of blood are flowing beneath our feet, Abbe.

turns.speaker: COULMIER
turns.text: If it were up to the Doctor, you'd be flayed alive.

turns.speaker: THE MARQUIS
turns.text: A man after my own heart...

turns.speaker: COULMIER
turns.text: What in God's name am I to do with you? The more I forbid, the more you're provoked!

turns.speaker: THE MARQUIS
turns.text: I could be convinced to abandon my writing, quite voluntarily.

turns.speaker: COULMIER
turns.text: What on earth would that require?

turns.speaker: THE MARQUIS
turns.text: A night spent with the partner of my choice.

turns.speaker: COULMIER
turns.text: You expect me to pimp Madeleine?

turns.speaker: THE MARQUIS
turns.text: I wasn't talking about Madeleine.

turns.speaker: COULMIER
turns.text: OFF WITH YOUR CLOTHES!

turns.speaker: THE MARQUIS
turns.text: Coulmier, you animal!

turns.speaker: COULMIER
turns.text: I DO NOT MEAN TO FLIRT, MARQUIS!

turns.speaker: THE MARQUIS
turns.text: Oh, but you must, my pumpkin! Sex without flirtation is merely rape!

turns.speaker: COULMIER
turns.text: NOW STRIP.

turns.speaker: THE MARQUIS
turns.text: It's a potent aphrodisiac, isn't it? Power over another man.

turns.speaker: COULMIER
turns.text: Your wig. Remove your wig.

turns.speaker: THE MARQUIS
turns.text: Oh, I'm to be blamed now, am I?

turns.speaker: COULMIER
turns.text: Your words drove Bouchon to --

turns.speaker: THE MARQUIS
turns.text: For fuck's sake, Abbe! What am I to do? Police my readers as you police me? Suppose one of your precious wards had attempted to walk on water and drowned? Would you condemn the Bible? I think not!

turns.speaker: COULMIER
turns.text: An innocent child is dead.

turns.speaker: THE MARQUIS
turns.text: So many authors are denied the gratification of a concrete response to their work. I am blessed, am I not?

turns.speaker: COULMIER
turns.text: It's no secret that you loved her.

turns.speaker: THE MARQUIS
turns.text: Oh, that's rich -- coming from her lapdog --

turns.speaker: COULMIER
turns.text: I saw the longing in your eye --

turns.speaker: THE MARQUIS
turns.text: -- that was lust --

turns.speaker: COULMIER
turns.text: -- the passion in your heart --

turns.speaker: THE MARQUIS
turns.text: Don't confuse one organ with another --

turns.speaker: COULMIER
turns.text: I know, because I felt it myself --

turns.speaker: THE MARQUIS
turns.text: I WANTED TO FUCK HER, THAT'S ALL!

turns.speaker: COULMIER
turns.text: AND DID YOU?

turns.speaker: THE MARQUIS
turns.text: IT'S NOT YOUR PROVINCE TO ASK.

turns.speaker: COULMIER
turns.text: You're no stranger to rape, Marquis; and yet with her, you cooed. You courted. You begged.

turns.speaker: THE MARQUIS
turns.text: Go to hell!

turns.speaker: COULMIER
turns.text: Why was it you never took her by force?

turns.speaker: THE MARQUIS
turns.text: Who's to say I did not?

turns.speaker: COULMIER
turns.text: Was it impotence?

turns.speaker: THE MARQUIS
turns.text: NEVER!

turns.speaker: COULMIER
turns.text: Then it must've been love --

turns.speaker: THE MARQUIS
turns.text: I FUCKED HER COUNTLESS TIMES! IN EVERY ORIFICE! AND ALL THE WHILE, SHE PLEAD FOR MORE --

turns.speaker: COULMIER
turns.text: We inspected the body, Marquis. She died a virgin.

turns.speaker: THE MARQUIS
turns.text: I dare you. Stab my flesh. Which one of us will bleed?

turns.speaker: COULMIER
turns.text: Tomorrow, we'll cut out your tongue.

turns.speaker: THE MARQUIS
turns.text: Abbe de Coulmier!

turns.speaker: COULMIER
turns.text: I'm here.

turns.speaker: THE MARQUIS
turns.text: Surely you'll grant me a final word.

turns.speaker: COULMIER
turns.text: Of course.

turns.speaker: COULMIER
turns.text: Dr. Royer-Collard? May I be the first to welcome you to Charenton --

turns.speaker: ROYER-COLLARD
turns.text: This may feel a tad awkward, my friend, but it needn't be. I've merely come to oversee your work here; understood?

turns.speaker: COULMIER
turns.text: Of course.

turns.speaker: ROYER-COLLARD
turns.text: It's a formality; truly.

turns.speaker: COULMIER
turns.text: You're a man of Science; I'm a man of God. Charenton stands to profit from us both, I'm certain.

turns.speaker: ROYER-COLLARD
turns.text: I'll need an office on the grounds; someplace to store my things.

turns.speaker: COULMIER
turns.text: If you don't mind my asking... why has the Emperor taken such sudden interest in my... our... affairs?

turns.speaker: ROYER-COLLARD
turns.text: It seems a particular patient of yours has captured his fancy.

turns.speaker: ROYER-COLLARD
turns.text: I understand he practices the very crimes he preaches in his fiction.

turns.speaker: COULMIER
turns.text: A few indiscretions in his youth.

turns.speaker: ROYER-COLLARD
turns.text: Indiscretions, Abbe? Please. I've read his case history. At sixteen, he violated a serving girl with a crucifix. After six months in the dungeon at Vincennes, he mutilated a prostitute, cutting her flesh with a razor, then cauterizing the wounds with wax --

turns.speaker: COULMIER
turns.text: I hope you'll judge him by his progress here, and not his past reputation.

turns.speaker: COULMIER
turns.text: He's made a great success of our Little Theater; there's seldom an empty seat. Not to mention its therapeutic value.

turns.speaker: ROYER-COLLARD
turns.text: Playing dress-up with cretins? That sounds like a symptom of madness; not its cure.

turns.speaker: ROYER-COLLARD
turns.text: Why is he in your care, and not a proper prison?

turns.speaker: COULMIER
turns.text: His wife's influence.

turns.speaker: ROYER-COLLARD
turns.text: His wife's?

turns.speaker: COULMIER
turns.text: Better to have an insane spouse than a criminal one.

turns.speaker: ROYER-COLLARD
turns.text: And he's never once attempted escape?

turns.speaker: COULMIER
turns.text: A man of his notoriety? He wouldn't last a day on the streets without capture.

turns.speaker: COULMIER
turns.text: Besides, every wholesome thing he might desire, he has at Charenton. A library, filled with the world's great books, music lessons, watercolor exercises --

turns.speaker: ROYER-COLLARD
turns.text: What is the impact of all these amenities upon his psyche?

turns.speaker: COULMIER
turns.text: He no longer roars or spits. He no longer taunts the guards or molests his fellow wards --

turns.speaker: ROYER-COLLARD
turns.text: And his writing?

turns.speaker: COULMIER
turns.text: Oh. That.

turns.speaker: ROYER-COLLARD
turns.text: Well...?

turns.speaker: COULMIER
turns.text: It's essential to his recovery; a purgative for the toxins in his mind.

turns.speaker: ROYER-COLLARD
turns.text: Do you favor its publication?

turns.speaker: COULMIER
turns.text: For sale? To the general public? Certainly not; it's unprintable.

turns.speaker: COULMIER
turns.text: You have to believe me, I had no idea --

turns.speaker: ROYER-COLLARD
turns.text: All France is aghast at this book, yet you've not heard of it?

turns.speaker: COULMIER
turns.text: I've taken vows to live my life within these walls; not outside them.

turns.speaker: ROYER-COLLARD
turns.text: Abbe, I admire you; I do. You've a conviction... an idealism... peculiar to the very young. And so I'll be candid. The Ministry has sent me here with the most explicit... the most severe instructions.

turns.speaker: COULMIER
turns.text: Yes?

turns.speaker: ROYER-COLLARD
turns.text: Unless we set Charenton on a straight and narrow course, she'll be shut down forever by order of the Emperor.

turns.speaker: COULMIER
turns.text: Shut down?

turns.speaker: ROYER-COLLARD
turns.text: In their eyes, the Marquis is the surest barometer of your progress here.

turns.speaker: COULMIER
turns.text: But he's one among some two hundred wards --

turns.speaker: ROYER-COLLARD
turns.text: Have you tried bleeding him with leeches? The calming chair? Maybe you should flog him at the stake?

turns.speaker: COULMIER
turns.text: Why? So he'll learn to fear punishment, rather than pursue virtue for its own reward?

turns.speaker: ROYER-COLLARD
turns.text: You're a sentimental man.

turns.speaker: COULMIER
turns.text: A practical man, sir. Given the Marquis' unusual tastes, a sound thrashing on bare flesh may not qualify as a deterrent.

turns.speaker: ROYER-COLLARD
turns.text: You find this amusing, do you?

turns.speaker: COULMIER
turns.text: On the contrary. Let me take up this matter with the Marquis myself --

turns.speaker: ROYER-COLLARD
turns.text: And place my reputation at stake?

turns.speaker: COULMIER
turns.text: Charenton is my life's work. To have her wrested from beneath me now --

turns.speaker: ROYER-COLLARD
turns.text: Well?

turns.speaker: COULMIER
turns.text: I spoke to him with reason and compassion; the tools which serve us best here.

turns.speaker: ROYER-COLLARD
turns.text: And --?

turns.speaker: COULMIER
turns.text: He's sworn to obedience.

turns.speaker: COULMIER
turns.text: He's more than a patient, Doctor; the Marquis is my friend --

turns.speaker: ROYER-COLLARD
turns.text: You keep strange company, Abbe. But if you truly have matters in hand here --

turns.speaker: COULMIER
turns.text: I have.

turns.speaker: ROYER-COLLARD
turns.text: -- then I've friends of my own to visit.

turns.speaker: COULMIER
turns.text: Madame Bougival; Mademoiselle Clairwil -- and of course -- the Marquis' wife --

turns.speaker: ROYER-COLLARD
turns.text: Oh indeed?

turns.speaker: COULMIER
turns.text: It was fiction, of course.

turns.speaker: ROYER-COLLARD
turns.text: Of course.

turns.speaker: COULMIER
turns.text: It was not inspired by circumstance.

turns.speaker: ROYER-COLLARD
turns.text: No. It most certainly was not.

turns.speaker: ROYER-COLLARD
turns.text: You ought to be ashamed, Abbe. Exploiting those drooling, pathetic cretins for financial gain --

turns.speaker: COULMIER
turns.text: That's not our intent --

turns.speaker: ROYER-COLLARD
turns.text: -- a veritable freak show for tourists and curiosity seekers. Charenton is a sanatorium; she is not a circus. The theater is henceforth closed. As for your avowed friend -- playwright emeritus of the madhouse --

turns.speaker: COULMIER
turns.text: I'll do everything in my power --

turns.speaker: ROYER-COLLARD
turns.text: Do more. Otherwise, I'll be forced to report to the Ministry that the inmates are indeed running the asylum.

turns.speaker: COULMIER
turns.text: You'll get more from her with kindness than you will with force.

turns.speaker: ROYER-COLLARD
turns.text: What could cause a tincture like this?

turns.speaker: ROYER-COLLARD
turns.text: He'll do no such thing.

turns.speaker: COULMIER
turns.text: It's a weak man who tests his mettle on the backs of children --

turns.speaker: ROYER-COLLARD
turns.text: This child let loose the beast from its cage --

turns.speaker: COULMIER
turns.text: Madeleine's not wicked. It's the Marquis who's corrupted her. That's not her fault; it's mine.

turns.speaker: COULMIER
turns.text: If only blood will appease you, then shed mine.

turns.speaker: ROYER-COLLARD
turns.text: You'd suffer in her stead?

turns.speaker: COULMIER
turns.text: As you say, Doctor.

turns.speaker: ROYER-COLLARD
turns.text: He was so impressed with the Marquis' tale that he chose to re-enact it, yes?

turns.speaker: ROYER-COLLARD
turns.text: Perhaps you'll be so kind as to remind me of her name...

turns.speaker: COULMIER
turns.text: I beg you, Doctor, don't make me say it.

turns.speaker: ROYER-COLLARD
turns.text: HER NAME, ABBE.

turns.speaker: ROYER-COLLARD
turns.text: My, my. You have exceeded my expectations.

turns.speaker: COULMIER
turns.text: And my own.

turns.speaker: ROYER-COLLARD
turns.text: How is the patient faring?

turns.speaker: COULMIER
turns.text: Poorly.

turns.speaker: ROYER-COLLARD
turns.text: And you? It must've been an ordeal.

turns.speaker: COULMIER
turns.text: I'm not the first man God has asked to shed blood in His name. I will not be the last.

turns.speaker: ROYER-COLLARD
turns.text: Will you sleep soundly tonight?

turns.speaker: COULMIER
turns.text: No, sir. Plainly put, I never expect to sleep again.

turns.speaker: COULMIER
turns.text: I've stared into the face of evil...  ...and I've lived to tell the tale. Now... for your own sake... let me write it down.

turns.speaker: ROYER-COLLARD
turns.text: Gibberish, my friend. He rants and he raves --

turns.speaker: DELBENÈ
turns.text: "As he loosened his manhood from beneath his robes, The Bishop muttered a Latin prayer. And then -- with a mighty thrust -- drove it into her very entrails --"

turns.speaker: NAPOLEON
turns.text: Enough!

turns.speaker: NAPOLEON
turns.text: As for the author... shoot him.

turns.speaker: DELBENÈ
turns.text: A word of caution, Sire: we all remember what happened to Robespierre, Danton and Marat. Put the Marquis to death, and history might even regard you as a despot.

turns.speaker: NAPOLEON
turns.text: But I am history.

turns.speaker: DELBENÈ
turns.text: Of course, Your Highness. Nevertheless... cure the Marquis de Sade... succeed, where countless physicians and priests have failed...

turns.speaker: NAPOLEON
turns.text: Yes?

turns.speaker: DELBENÈ
turns.text: No one can fault Napoleon for merely bringing a man to his senses.

turns.speaker: ROYER-COLLARD
turns.text: But here at the Hotel Dieu we favor an... aggressive... course of treatment.

turns.speaker: DELBENÈ
turns.text: Quite.

turns.speaker: ROYER-COLLARD
turns.text: I don't seek popularity or renown, Monsieur Delbenè. Mine is a higher mission.

turns.speaker: ROYER-COLLARD
turns.text: Charenton? The administrator there is quite well-loved, is he not?

turns.speaker: DELBENÈ
turns.text: I'm afraid so; he's an idealist. You'll have to be politic.

turns.speaker: ROYER-COLLARD
turns.text: Do you know how I define "idealism," Monsieur Delbenè?

turns.speaker: DELBENÈ
turns.text: His wife was trying to escape; they caught her on the stair, and set upon her with bayonets.  "There but for the grace of God"... eh, Doctor?

turns.speaker: ROYER-COLLARD
turns.text: I don't shed tears over the past, Monsieur Delbenè; I look to the future.

turns.speaker: MADELEINE
turns.text: Here it is; the last chapter.

turns.speaker: HORSEMAN
turns.text: Monsieur Masse says he'd like another manuscript, quick as you please. He's got himself three presses, and he can't print 'em fast enough.

turns.speaker: MADELEINE
turns.text: I'll pass the word on, then.

turns.speaker: HORSEMAN
turns.text: I'll pay you another visit, with a share of the profits, once its sold.

turns.speaker: MADELEINE
turns.text: I'll be waiting.

turns.speaker: HORSEMAN
turns.text: Maybe someday you'll tell me your name.

turns.speaker: MADELEINE
turns.text: You asked my name once; it's Madeleine.

turns.speaker: HORSEMAN
turns.text: Sweet, then? Like the pastry?

turns.speaker: LIBERTINE
turns.text: At last she arrives, my hard-won bride! Hurry, my child, and scurry inside. There you'll find such treasures await you; Marzipan and meringue to sate you!

turns.speaker: INGENUE
turns.text: Such gallantry in men is -- sadly -- a rarity; How lucky I am to receive his charity!

turns.speaker: LIBERTINE
turns.text: Quickly, my suckling, out of your clothes! My scepter awaits; how solid it grows!

turns.speaker: INGENUE
turns.text: Stop, I beg you! Have pity, I say! You're not my lover; you're a monstrous rouè!

turns.speaker: LIBERTINE
turns.text: My darling, Eugenie, dainty morsel! Get on your back! Let's try it dorsal!

turns.speaker: INGENUE
turns.text: Was ever a man more risquè? He wants to take me every way!

turns.speaker: LIBERTINE
turns.text: I'll plunder every lovely pore until you're week and cry "no more!"

turns.speaker: INGENUE
turns.text: I tremble with fear! You're bound to pound the quivering lips of my Venus mound!

turns.speaker: LIBERTINE
turns.text: And then -- to prove your truly mine -- I'll plunder you, darling, from behind!

turns.speaker: INGENUE
turns.text: What of my lips, will you soil them too? When you've broken every other taboo?

turns.speaker: LIBERTINE
turns.text: I'll fill every slippery hollow; if you're obliging, then you'll swallow!

turns.speaker: MADAME LECLERC
turns.text: If you won't read it to your own Mama, then perhaps you ought not to be reading it at all.

turns.speaker: MADELEINE
turns.text: It's not your cup of tea, Mama.

turns.speaker: MADAME LECLERC
turns.text: Come now, darling, give it a read.

turns.speaker: MADELEINE
turns.text: "A habituè of cemeteries, his proudest conquest was a maid six decades his senior, deceased a dozen years."

turns.speaker: MADAME LECLERC
turns.text: Oh, it's terrible! It's too, too terrible!  Well. Go on.

turns.speaker: MADELEINE
turns.text: "The vigor with which he made love caused her bones to dislodge. Still, he granted her the highest compliment he accorded any woman..."

turns.speaker: MADAME LECLERC
turns.text: Yes?

turns.speaker: MADELEINE
turns.text: "Well worth the dig!"

turns.speaker: MADELEINE
turns.text: I'm only a laundress; not a detective.

turns.speaker: MADAME LECLERC
turns.text: Now's not the time to be cheeky, Maddy.

turns.speaker: MADAME LECLERC
turns.text: You're more than a priest; you're an angel! Ain't he, Maddy?

turns.speaker: MADELEINE
turns.text: It's because of the Marquis, isn't it?

turns.speaker: THE MARQUIS
turns.text: I'm hungry for a proper visit.

turns.speaker: MADELEINE
turns.text: Don't start --

turns.speaker: THE MARQUIS
turns.text: Go ahead; you've a key. Slip it through my tiny hole...

turns.speaker: THE MARQUIS
turns.text: Did I frighten you?

turns.speaker: MADELEINE
turns.text: You? Frighten me? That's a good one! I'm twice as fast as you are. Who'd have thought such a spent body can still boast such a fertile mind?

turns.speaker: THE MARQUIS
turns.text: It's the only frontier I have left, plumcake.

turns.speaker: MADELEINE
turns.text: I suppose you want to know about that silly book of yours.

turns.speaker: THE MARQUIS
turns.text: The peril of composing such incendiary prose...

turns.speaker: MADELEINE
turns.text: I put myself at life and limb. Surely that's worth a few louis.

turns.speaker: THE MARQUIS
turns.text: If only these coins purchased your other talents, too.

turns.speaker: MADELEINE
turns.text: There's something else I want from you.

turns.speaker: THE MARQUIS
turns.text: You've already stolen my heart, as well as another more prominent organ, south of the Equator...

turns.speaker: MADELEINE
turns.text: Your publisher says I'm not to leave without a new manuscript.

turns.speaker: THE MARQUIS
turns.text: I've just the story... inspired by these very surroundings....
